title: 106_s2324
content: The "Ballistics, Law Assistance, and Safety Technology Act" (BLAST) aims to increase public safety by assisting law enforcement in solving gun-related crimes through ballistics technology. It requires ballistics testing of new firearms for sale and firearms in custody of Federal agencies to aid in identifying firearms used in crimes. Additionally, it adds ballistics testing to existing firearms enforcement programs and enables targeted enforcement of Federal firearms laws. SEC. 101 of the "Ballistics, Law Assistance, and Safety Technology Act" (BLAST) defines ballistics as the analysis of fired bullets and cartridge casings to identify the firearm used. SEC. 102 involves test firing and automated storage of ballistics records. Amendment to Section 923 of title 18, United States Code requires licensed manufacturers or importers to test fire firearms, prepare ballistics images, store records in a database, and store fired bullet and cartridge casings as specified by the Secretary. No civil liability except for civil penalties imposed under this section. The Attorney General and the Secretary will assist firearm manufacturers and importers in complying with requirements related to ballistics equipment, bullet recovery equipment, database maintenance, education on ballistics, and coordination with law enforcement agencies to reduce firearm-related crime. The Attorney General and the Secretary will establish a computer system for law enforcement access to ballistics records and encourage training for examiners. They will also submit annual reports on the impact of these measures on reducing firearm-related crime. The Attorney General and the Secretary will establish a computer system for law enforcement access to ballistics records and encourage training for examiners. They will also submit annual reports on the impact of these measures on reducing firearm-related crime. Additionally, there is authorized funding for Federal and State criminal investigations utilizing ballistics records, evaluating accessibility across jurisdictions, and conducting test programs under the Ballistics, Law Assistance, and State Technology Act. $20,000,000 is allocated for fiscal years 2001 through 2004 for equipment installation, testing sites, personnel salaries, and expenses. The Secretary and the Attorney General will conduct mandatory ballistics testing of firearms in their possession. The effective date of this amendment depends on the interoperability of ballistics systems between the Department of Justice and the Department of the Treasury. The amendment to title 18, United States Code, will take effect upon enactment of this Act. SEC. 103. PRIVACY RIGHTS OF LAW ABIDING CITIZENS. Ballistics information of individual guns may not be used for prosecutorial purposes unless law enforcement has reasonable belief of a crime. SEC. 104. DEMONSTRATION FIREARM CRIME REDUCTION STRATEGY. The Secretary of the Treasury and the Attorney General must establish a firearm crime reduction strategy within 60 days of the Act's enactment. The strategy includes ballistics testing of recovered firearms to identify types, origins, suspects, and link crimes involving the same firearm. The legislation aims to enhance firearm tracing and ballistics testing to identify illegal firearms traffickers and establish trends in firearm-related crime and trafficking. Coordination among law enforcement officials at all levels is required for effective investigation and prosecution of firearms-related crimes. The legislation aims to enhance firearm tracing and ballistics testing to identify illegal firearms traffickers. The Secretary of the Treasury and the Attorney General will select at least 10 jurisdictions for participation in the program, prioritizing those with comprehensive firearm law enforcement strategies. Jurisdictions must also draft a plan to share ballistics records with nearby jurisdictions. The legislation authorizes $20,000,000 for fiscal years 2001 through 2004 to expand ballistics testing, including equipment installation and personnel expenses from the Department of Justice and the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, and Firearms. SEC. 201. TARGETED ENFORCEMENT OF FEDERAL FIREARMS LAWS. The Attorney General and the Secretary of the Treasury will designate at least 50 local jurisdictions to aggressively enforce Federal laws preventing criminals from possessing firearms. They may provide assistance by detailing Federal personnel and coordinating activities with State and local officials. The Attorney General and Secretary of the Treasury will designate local jurisdictions to enforce Federal laws preventing criminals from possessing firearms. This includes coordinating activities with State and local officials, training law enforcement officers, and conducting public outreach on penalties for violations. Criteria for designation include high rates of recidivism. The Attorney General and Secretary of the Treasury will designate local jurisdictions based on criteria such as high rates of recidivism among armed felons, violent crime levels, resources allocated by law enforcement agencies to combat illegal possession of firearms, the need for increased federal resources, and any other relevant criteria deemed appropriate. Priority will be given to local jurisdictions that have shown commitment to enforcing federal firearms laws through initiatives like the Youth Crime Gun Interdiction Initiative, Project Disarm, and Operation Ceasefire. Additionally, jurisdictions identifying a high number of convicted felons involved in firearms trafficking to individuals under 25 and agreeing to promptly submit identifying information on recovered firearms to the Secretary of the Treasury will also receive priority designation. The Attorney General and the Secretary of the Treasury must submit an annual report to Congress on arrests, prosecutions, and convictions related to illegal firearms possession by criminals in designated cities. The report should also include information on public outreach efforts. The Attorney General and the Secretary of the Treasury must submit a report to Congress on the effectiveness of designated jurisdictions in reducing crime, along with any recommendations for legislation. $5,000,000 is authorized for fiscal years 2001 through 2004 to carry out this section.
